citation.article-title: Bacteroides coprophilus sp. nov., isolated from human faeces.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Bacteroides coprophilus sp. nov.
Bacteroides coprophilus (cop.ro′phi.lus. Gr. n. copros dung, faeces; Gr. masc. adj. philos friendly to; N.L. masc. adj. coprophilus loving faeces).
Cells are anaerobic, non-spore-forming, Gram-negative short rods or rods.
Colonies on EG agar plates after 48 h incubation at 37 °C under 100 % CO2 are circular, dark grey, translucent and convex.
Grows in the presence of bile.
No activity is detected for urease or gelatin.
Acid is produced from d-glucose, lactose, maltose, d-mannose, d-raffinose and sucrose.

Positive reactions are obtained using the API Rapid ID 32A system for N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, alkaline phosphatase, α-fucosidase, α-galactosidase, β-galactosidase, α-glucosidase, β-glucosidase and alanine, arginine, histidine, leucine and leucyl glycine arylamidases.

Negative reactions are obtained for α-arabinosidase, arginine dihydrolase, β-galactosidase 6-phosphate, β-glucuronidase, glutamic acid decarboxylase, nitrate reductase, indole, proline arylamidase and pyroglutamic acid arylamidase.
The major end products are succinic and acetic acids; small amounts of isovaleric acid, propionic acid and pyruvic acid are also produced.
Major fatty acids are anteiso-C15 : 0 (12–16 %), C16 : 0 (9–12 %), iso-C17 : 0 3-OH (17–19 %) and C18 : 1ω9c (16–18 %).
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 44.7 mol%.
The type strain, CB42T (=JCM 13818T=DSM 18228T), was isolated from human faeces.
Strains CB40 (=JCM 13816) and CB41 (=JCM 13817) are included in this species.
